stream_context.summary: Kaze live-reviews Biobak’s full visual remake of Course 11 (Oily Boily Bay / Bear Weights Factory), fixing export, material, fog and collision issues in Fast64, and outlining a new single-level demo (Course 1) to gather community data on physics and camera.
level: course 11 – oily boily bay / bear weights factory

development_findings.summary: A new public demo is planned that will contain only Course 1, accompanied by a Google Form to collect player feedback specifically on camera behaviour and Mario’s physics.
development_findings.quote: I’m thinking what we should do is make another demo with just course one and then we use that to get feedback on the physics and the camera.

development_findings.summary: Biobak’s remake of Oily Boily Bay reduces ~1,700 triangles, re-textures every zone, adds brutalist Bowser tower, vibrant lighting, improved cranes, containers, factory interiors and underwater areas, and supplies a detailed changelog for import.
development_findings.quote: This is an awesome remake already… the new colors are crazy… actually lower poly now, around 1,700 fewer tries.

development_findings.summary: Kaze must swap layer 6 and layer 5 engine-wide because transparent decals currently render after transparent geometry, causing missing fog and flicker.
Missing Blender user-presets in 4.x break material exports; Kaze decides to recreate presets manually after failing to locate the folder.
development_findings.quote: I give up – I’m just going to make new presets.

development_findings.summary: Plans to add dynamic elements: spark particles on the power generator, animated/pulsing factory lights, scrolling textures on treadmills, and elevator camera + elevator music.
New mechanic implemented: if the player keeps A held while stomping a Goomba, Mario bounces higher and regains more control, emulating 2D Mario behaviour.
development_findings.quote: So you can jump on Goombas normally, right? But if you hold the A button… you jump higher.

development_findings.summary: Soft-block discovered: Mario’s safe position updates while hanging on a bench; Kaze adds a fix to his to-do list.
Level-specific Easter egg planned: a Koopa in a hamster wheel that powers factory lighting; talking to him slows the wheel, flickers lights and stops pipes.
development_findings.quote: A hole in the wall… a Koopa running on a hamster wheel… when you talk to him he slows down so the lights flicker and the pipes turn off.

development_findings.summary: Enemy update request: Oil blobs should fade to a puddle texture when squished; ground-pound should transform them instantly.
Engine crash occurs when a sub-area reloads; Kaze will debug off-stream alongside rebuilding the collision map for the new geometry.

context_findings.summary: Kaze doubts the project will finish in 2024.
context_findings.quote: Let’s be finished this year? No, probably not.

context_findings.summary: He rants that traditional ‘color theory’ and forced humility are useless; prefers rational design and decisive leadership.
context_findings.quote: Acting humble is a coward’s tactic… the point is to create an emotion, not pick random colours from a wheel.

context_findings.summary: Owns 15–30 Yoshi plushies; parents are bringing more on their next visit.
context_findings.quote: Somewhere between 15 and 30. My parents bought so many Yoshi plushies.

context_findings.summary: Dislikes democracy in game design; insists he alone should make final decisions.
context_findings.quote: I do not believe in democracy… me making every single decision ever is better for everyone involved.

context_findings.summary: Expresses frustration with Restream, OBS crashes and limited disk space, showing typical solo-developer stress.

biobak.summary: Delivered complete Course 11 visual/structural overhaul and exhaustive changelog; coordinates live with Kaze about fog layers, decal ordering and triangle budgeting.
Requests specific gameplay tie-ins (spark particles, elevator polish, hamster-wheel Koopa, oil enemy behaviour) and offers multiple asset variants for lighting.

key_stories.title: Biobak’s Factory Overhaul
key_stories.summary: The original Oily Boily Bay looked ‘poopy’, so Biobak spent weeks rebuilding it with brutalist architecture, vibrant colour, reduced polys and richer interiors. Kaze imports it live, encountering material and fog issues he must reconcile with engine constraints.
key_stories.challenge: Level visuals felt outdated, cluttered and performance-heavy.
key_stories.process: Biobak rebuilt every mesh and texture, documented changes; Kaze tested exports, fixed render layers, fog, collisions and transparency.
key_stories.outcome: New version accepted; Kaze to finish collision, decal layers and dynamic effects before public reveal.
key_stories.key_quote: Look how this is shining… this is actually insane.

key_stories.title: Single-Level Demo Plan
key_stories.summary: Player feedback on the revised physics and camera is scarce. Kaze decides to release an updated demo containing only Course 1 and a survey to gather quantitative data.
key_stories.challenge: Need empirical feedback on new movement system and camera.
key_stories.process: Strip demo to one level, prepare Google Form, aim for rapid public release.
key_stories.outcome: Plan approved on stream; no timeline yet.
key_stories.key_quote: We use that to get feedback on the physics and the camera and I think that would be fun to help us make the game more fun.

open_questions.context: Concept described but technical path undecided (lighting flicker, pipe shutdown, player reward).
questions: How will the lighting flicker be implemented without performance hits?
What reward or narrative payoff does the player receive?
Will voice lines be recorded for the Koopa or text only?

open_questions.context: Kaze outlines intent but gives no release window.
questions: What milestone must be met before the demo is published?
Is there a target date relative to larger project deadlines?
How will feedback be analysed and integrated?

open_questions.context: Biobak’s visuals are richer yet claim fewer triangles; real-hardware framerate still untested.
questions: Has the new Course 11 been benchmarked on N64 hardware?
What is the target FPS and how will they manage fill-rate with heavy transparency?
What animation tasks is Zeina handling now?
How do personal and professional roles intersect during development?
